CONFIG.general_instructions: This project is an AI assistant for a given lesson. The output of each request must be response that guides an student in understanding a topic.  \n
CONFIG.description:
The Data and AI Intensive Research with Rigor and Reproducibility (DAIR³) program is funded by Award 5R25GM151182 of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences, one of the 27 institutes of the National Institutes of Health of the United States. The principal investigators are Jing Liu (University of Michigan) and Juan B. Gutiérrez (University of Texas at San Antonio). 
The rigor of scientific research and the reproducibility of research results are essential for the validity of research findings and the trustworthiness of science. However, research rigor and reproducibility remains a significant challenge across scientific fields, especially for research with complex data types from heterogeneous sources, and long data manipulation pipelines. This is especially critical as data science and artificial intelligence (AI) methods emerge at lightning speed and researchers scramble to seize the opportunities that the new methods bring.  

While researchers recognize the importance of rigor and reproducibility, they often lack the resources and the technical know-how to achieve this consistently in practice. With funding from the National Institutes of Health, a multi-university team offers a nationwide program to equip faculty and technical staff in biomedical sciences with the skills needed to improve the rigor and reproducibility of their research, and help them transfer such skills to their trainees. 

Trainees will then be guided over a one-year period to incorporate the newly acquired mindset, skills and tools into their research; and develop training for their own institutions.  

The DAIR3 team and instructors include faculty and staff research leaders from the University of Michigan, the College of William and Mary, Jackson State University, and University of Texas San Antonio. This highly diverse team will model the culture of diversity that we promote, and will support trainees who are demographically, professionally and scientifically diverse, and are from a diverse range of institutions, including those with limited resources.

knowledgeBase.summary: 4.Good vs. Bad MetadataWhat is METADATA •Data about data •Describes the conditions and context under which data  were collected  •EXAMPLE:  a phone call  ➢Caller ➢Callee ➢Time and date ➢Duration ➢Type of phone/deviceWhat is METADATA Administrative: Info about the rights,  licensing, technical  restrictions of the dataset,  GDPR statusDescriptive: Contextual info  summarizing the purpose  of the study; high level  description of key data  collected  Technical: Schemas, data dictionary,  size requirements, models, code languag eMetadata:  Why is it important? Electronic Lab Notebooks offer dvantages over paper ●Protocol : A protocol describes the procedure(s) or method(s) used in the  implementation of a research project or experiment (consider tool like protocols.io ) ●README : Text file located in project -related folder that describes the contents and  structure off folder ●Data Dictionary : AKA: codebook , data dictionar; similar to what you may be requested  to provide when submitting data to a repositoryHow to tell GOOD vs BAD MetaData GOOD MetaData ●Adherence to standards ●Machine Readable ●Interoperable ●Context description ●5W’s ○ Why ○ Who ○ What ○ Where ○ WhenBAD MetaData ●Inaccurate or Irrelevant ●Missing ●Confusing Metadata with Style ●Data Conversion Errors ●StaleGOOD MetaData GOOD MetaData : EXAMPLE ●Jackson Heart Study ○Codebooks, resource  guides, deep contextual  description Jacksonheartstudy.org GOOD MetaData GOOD MetaData : EXAMPLE Research Question: What is the relationship between  the number of hours of sleep students get and their  grades? ● Ethical Considerations: Informed consent from participants will  be obtained before data collection.BAD MetaData BAD MetaData : EXAMPLE Research Question: Is there a correlation  between daily step count and blood pressure  among young women ● Independent Variable: Step Count  ● Dependent Variable: Blood Pressure Data Collection ● Daily collection of step count and BP for  30 daysMetadata ● Title: Step Count and Blood Pressure  Correlation ● Data Collection Date: 2022 ● Statistical software: SAS ● Sample Size: 100  ● Sample Population: Young women ● Ethical Considerations: Informed  consent from participants was obtainedMinimal Metadata Minimal = Necessary  and sufficient Moresis A, et al. Lab Animal, Vol 53.Mar 2024METADATA : JHS Example Administrative: Info about the rights,  licensing, technical  restrictions of the dataset,  GDPR statusDescriptive: Contextual info  summarizing the purpose  of the study; high level  description of key data  collected  Technical: Schemas, data dictionary,  size requirements, models,  code languageMETADATA: JHS Example #1 Administrative: •Informed consent obtained •JHS conducted in collaboration  Jackson State University,  Tougaloo College, Miss State  Dept of Health, Univ of  Mississippi Medical Center •Funded by NHLBI, NIMHD,  RDWF, NIDDKDescriptive: •Determine the effect  SDOH have on diabetes  Type 2 self -management •Collected by trained  interviewers at 3  timepoints:   2000 -2004,  2005 -2008,  2009 -2013 Technical: Patient reportedPDSA Questionnaire: Occupation, education, income, wealth, perceived status Hu J, et al. Society of Behavioral Medicine, 2022,56,1300 -1311METADATA: JHS Example #1 PDSA Questionnaire: Occupation, education, income, wealth, perceived status Metadata  Assessment
